blog.name: webofstarwars
blog.title: Web of Star Wars
blog.description: A collection of cool, unique, and behind the scenes Star Wars pics, videos, and news. Twitter @LordGuvna

title: My thoughts on Solo
body:
I went and saw Solo last night and, although didn’t like everything about it, overall, I did like it.  I liked the plot and I liked the twists.  The way some of the events from Han’s past that we had heard about was done well I thought.  The effects were good of course and I liked finally seeing Corellia on the big screen!  I also think the music was great.  Not quite John Williams level, but I did like it better than Rogue One’s score (not saying Michael Giacchino’s score of Rogue One was bad, but this one was better).

I feel like Alden did a decent job of portraying Han’s personality, but he just doesn’t sound like Han to me.  Specifically what I mean is he just doesn’t sound like Harrison Ford, who for me (and most other people too I suspect), is Han Solo.  On the other hand, I thought Donald Glover did sound a lot like Billy Dee Williams sometimes, but other times he didn’t…which was odd to me.  

Another thing I thought was odd was the lighting and colors of the movie.  I didn’t feel like the plot had a dark tone, but the lighting and color did.  It seemed desaturated and gray, and at times could be quite dark.  Almost like a neo-noir look sometimes, but not really the feel of that type of film. 

I remember after the premier reading comments about world building and “Marvel-level shit” that had me wondering what would happen in the movie.  I  Ilked the ending and we already know what happens to Han and Lando later on in their lives.  But there is a bit of a twist before the ending that could possibly lead to a sequel or spinoff of this movie (it wouldn’t necessarily require Han to be in it, but considering Alden was contracted for more than one movie, he probably would be in it, even if it was just a cameo).  But it’s also possible the twist could just be a fan-service cameo that goes no where or told as a story in a book or comic. And it could depend on how well Solo does in the box office and reviews.  

Overall, it’s a good movie.  I still wish they would have just told a similar story with completely new characters or pulled characters from the EU instead of recasting iconic characters with new actors, but it is what it is.  If you like Star Wars, go see it for yourself and see what you think.

summary:
Rogue One, Gareth Edwards, 2016, EEUU Hazañas bélicas del espacio con
un improvisado comando armando una batalla descomunal para...
caption:
Rogue One, Gareth Edwards, 2016, EEUU

Hazañas bélicas del espacio con un improvisado comando armando una batalla descomunal para robar unos planos secretos. Más allá de la incoherencia de base, el modo de fabricar un suspense artificial en base a la exageración y su total falta de sentido fuera de la explotación comercial de una marca queda, bueno, una película corriente que tira de elementos igual de corrientes (conflictos paternofiliales, exceso de diálogo, obsesiones posmodernas y nostálgicas por rellenar/recuperar el pasado, necesidad de convertir en gris lo que nació para ser en blanco y negro…) dentro de una estructura deshilacha pero suficiente. Hecha al vejo estilo del nuevo Sistema, en decir, con diferentes directores, guionistas, etc…tomando las riendas sobre la marcha, carece de la unidad formal/estructural/tonal de sus equivalentes en el viejo Sistema. Así, planos de recreación minuciosa de sus precedentes conviven con otros que parecen de películas/épocas distintas en un conjunto de formulación televisiva, llena de planos pero sin imágenes memorables que continúa los robos a Miyazaki, en especial Nausicaä, y añade Dune o incluso Watchmen.

blog.name: anothermillennialreviewer
blog.description: A reviewer of films and a writer of poetry.

summary: Solo: A Star Wars Story Review
title: Solo: A Star Wars Story Review
body:
Spoilers. 

Solo: A Star Wars Story focuses on the early life of Han Solo. The events of the greater Star Wars Universe are not the focus here, with the story itself being far more self-contained. For me Alden Ehrenreich is a believable Han Solo, bringing the right amount of charisma to the role. However, he is greatly outshined by his on-screen peers, Woody Harrelson,(Tobias Beckett), Emilia Clarke, (Qi’ra) and of course Donald Glover, (Lando). Beckett is a father figure to Han throughout the film, and the two have a believable emotional bond.  Conversely, the relationship between Han and Chewbacca, (Joonas Suotamo), is lacking with scenes such as the life debt being left out, and the relationship, on the whole, being sidelined for the Han Qi'ra romance. Qi'ra is perhaps the best character as she is incredibly three-dimensional. Qi'ra is a very capable character as shown during third act fight scene with a sword; which is the action high point of the film. The best thing about the writing for Qi’ra’s character is that she is not written as merely  Han’s love interest, but instead as a very cunning character whose allegiance you can never be sure of.  Furthermore, the end of the film sets up her connections to Darth Maul, which as far as twists go is very welcome and satisfying.  Overall the shortcomings of the film are as follows, firstly the film relies far too heavily on nostalgia, with the constant use of Han’s dice becoming unbearable towards the end of the film. This is also reflected in the diegetic dialogue where character will say things that equate to, “remember that?”. Moreover, there is also the use of incredibly on the nose foreshadowing to hint at future events, such as when Qi’ra says something to the extent of, “Chewie needs you and I have a feeling you will need him to”. Furthermore, and this may the films greatest crime, there is no real villain, sure Paul Bettany’s Vos is menacing when he is on screen, but that equates to two scenes if that, with the film lacking real danger as a result. A final complaint is that Donald Glovers’ Lando is underused, he is the scene stealer of the film and seems to be punished for that fact by being given precious little to do. On the whole Solo is a lot better than I was expecting it to be, I believe that both hardcore fans and more passive viewers can find something to like here. I would recommend you see it.
3.5/5
Reviewed by Luke

blog.name: bethagain
blog.title: bethagain
blog.description: Began as a place to flail around about MM:FR, expanded into a place to flail around about other things too. You'll probably see some Star Wars, Star Trek, Sherlock, Inception, who knows what else! Occasional ruminations on life and reblogs of non-fandom things that made me smile. Fic resides at the same username on AO3.

tags: I have more thoughts but no more time right now
probably more later because this is my place for dumping Star Wars thinky stuff
summary: I saw the Han Solo movie. I wasn’t going to, at least not right away, because why give Disney my money if the movie was going to...
body:
I saw the Han Solo movie.

I wasn’t going to, at least not right away, because why give Disney my money if the movie was going to suck. But then my BFF was going to see it opening night, and of course I needed to be able to talk about it with her, so.

It didn’t suck, I’ll give it that. It was a servicable sci fi adventure. Except for that one moment near the end when I fell asleep, but that was probably because I went to the late show and I’m old.

The problem was, it felt workmanlike. It hit its plot points. It had some laughs. The CGI was decent. The actors acted. If this had been a plumbing job, it would have been a competent one. The basement isn’t flooded and we’re not going to need to replace the drywall.

A Star Wars movie should NEVER feel workmanlike.

A Star Wars movie needs to bring the magic. This one… didn’t.

I will say, I did like the sets, costumes, and overall design. It looked like the GFFA. It just didn’t feel like it.

It didn’t suck, I’ll give it that. It was a servicable sci fi adventure. Except for that one moment near the end when I fell asleep, but that was probably because I went to the late show and I’m old.

The problem was, it felt workmanlike. It hit its plot points. It had some laughs. The CGI was decent. The actors acted. If this had been a plumbing job, it would have been a competent one. The basement isn’t flooded and we’re not going to need to replace the drywall.

A Star Wars movie should NEVER feel workmanlike.

A Star Wars movie needs to bring the magic. This one… didn’t.

I will say, I did like the sets, costumes, and overall design. It looked like the GFFA. It just didn’t feel like it.

trail.content_raw:
I saw the Han Solo movie.

I wasn’t going to, at least not right away, because why give Disney my money if the movie was going to suck. But then my BFF was going to see it opening night, and of course I needed to be able to talk about it with her, so.

It didn’t suck, I’ll give it that. It was a servicable sci fi adventure. Except for that one moment near the end when I fell asleep, but that was probably because I went to the late show and I’m old.

The problem was, it felt workmanlike. It hit its plot points. It had some laughs. The CGI was decent. The actors acted. If this had been a plumbing job, it would have been a competent one. The basement isn’t flooded and we’re not going to need to replace the drywall.

A Star Wars movie should NEVER feel workmanlike.

A Star Wars movie needs to bring the magic. This one… didn’t.

I will say, I did like the sets, costumes, and overall design. It looked like the GFFA. It just didn’t feel like it.
trail.content:
I saw the Han Solo movie.

I wasn’t going to, at least not right away, because why give Disney my money if the movie was going to suck. But then my BFF was going to see it opening night, and of course I needed to be able to talk about it with her, so.

It didn’t suck, I’ll give it that. It was a servicable sci fi adventure. Except for that one moment near the end when I fell asleep, but that was probably because I went to the late show and I’m old.

The problem was, it felt workmanlike. It hit its plot points. It had some laughs. The CGI was decent. The actors acted. If this had been a plumbing job, it would have been a competent one. The basement isn’t flooded and we’re not going to need to replace the drywall.

A Star Wars movie should NEVER feel workmanlike.

A Star Wars movie needs to bring the magic. This one… didn’t.

I will say, I did like the sets, costumes, and overall design. It looked like the GFFA. It just didn’t feel like it.

summary: For anon...reader is Han’s sister as requested. Luke: Y/N! Y/N: *turns around* Luke! Both: *run toward each other* Han: *turns...
caption:
For anon…reader is Han’s sister as requested.

Luke: Y/N!
Y/N: *turns around* Luke!
Both: *run toward each other*
Han: *turns around* *pauses*
Luke: *kisses Y/N* Are you okay?
Y/N: *chuckles* Yes. Are you?
Luke: *lowering head* I gave him a proper burial.
Y/N: *rubs Luke’s back* You did the right thing.
Luke: *smiles* I know.
Han: *clears throat* Ummm.
Y/N: What? Waiting for a hug, Han? *giggles*
Han: Did…did you two just kiss? Are you two…are you together?
Luke: *lowers eyes* We forgot to tell him, didn’t we?
Y/N: *smirks* You realize you’re dating his sister, right?
Han: *pauses* Well, that’s-that’s different! I didn’t know she was his sister.
Y/N: Sorry Hanny-boy; can’t chase this one off.
Han: *purses lips*
Y/N: *ruffles hair* Come on. He’s not so bad.
Han: *smirks* Doesn’t mean I have to like it.
Luke: *chuckles* 

Perma-tags: @beeeeeeeeeeeeeeeep @ttelesilla @jumperswellies @caitsymichelle13 @myplaceofthingsilove @frostbyte-horan @bestillmystuckyheart @littlestfangirl
Semi-tags: @the-viking-chronicles

Request Here ; Submit Here

blog.name: thebaldingwookiee
blog.title: The Balding Wookiee
blog.description: Real Play Star Wars FFG Play by Post Page

body:
A Tight Spot VI

Destiny Pool: 5 Light, 5 Dark

*****

Gruk sees the repurposed battled droids lumber into the vast, oppulent, and gaudy entry hallway. Paar starts looking around trying to find a way to override systems, delay the inevitable or anything else.

Meanwhile, one of the security drones calls in for reinforcements, unbeknownst to our heroes.

Security Droid B1-8D7 takes aim and hits Gruk on his left shoulder. His partner, B1-RF73, sweeps wide to try to get a crossfire angle.

Simultaneously, Paar sees the Gungan cleaning lady lumbering through the foyer toward the service entrance that Gruk had seen earlier that day. Her cleaning droid is ponderousy rolling along before her. Paar seizes the opportunity, walks up murmuring a sweet “yib nub” to her. Fate, the force, kindly malevolence, call it what you will, but they’re instantly both aware that this has to be. The gungan sweeps the miniscule fur ball into her arms and begins to embrace him with wild abandon. Paar uses his free hand to pop open the panel on the side of the cleaning droid. He searches for something, anything…

B1-RF73 quirks his head to the side, muttering something about “meat-sacks.” He can’t look away. It is a space-freighter wreck on a whole new level. He tries to clear his processors to take a shot at the fuzz ball, but misses wildly, hitting a fresco of Hutts in some backroom deal from ages ago. RF73 had never understood aesthetics, but he though he has just improved them.

Gruk takes out his rope and lassos one of the security drones, flinging it into the legs of RF73.

8D7 reacts and still struggles with the sight of the cleaning lady and the Ewok in a warm embrace. He nevertheless still connects with Gruk for a second time.

Paar jumps up, flipping a switch that crosses the wire for the cleaning droid, causing the vacuum to open the manifolds and feed the intake back through the mainframe portion of his chassis. This causes a jump between the motivator and the powercore. The droid’s power fries flinging the gungan one way and the ewok gets catapulted. He comes to land in front of RF73. His helmet, on auto-fire blasts the droid once in his lower torso and once just below the head. The blasts nick the main power coupling wires between the torso and his processor causing a short that fries RF73’s motherboard.

8D7 reacts the only way he knows how: he tries to aim for Paar but is unsuccessful.

Gruk stares the final droid down, raises his blaster and lets go a blast which snaps the droid’s head back. It flails about for a moment only to fall still.

Dio, Na Mach, Rakk and Kimnu race into the room only to find the threat to be resolved. Everyone looks up in time to see the lone remaining security drone hiding close to the ceiling, two stories up, still blinking and whirring.

Stomp

Stomp

Stomp

Stomp

Four more upgraded B1 droids march into the foyer and fan out. Reinforcements have arrived.

*****

Destiny Pool: 8 Light & 2 Dark

blog.name: mouser26
blog.title: Mouse Nest
blog.description: I have no Idea what I'm doing

title: Star Wars thing
body:
ok so I can’t really explain how this came up or whatever but one of my coworkers today came up with this in response to some like “WHat would you do if you ran Lucas Films” question

“First thing I’d do is erect a statue. It would be a crashed X-Wing, like just right into the ground, and then looped over one of the blaster cannons would be a rope. One end of the rope is around Luke Skywalker’s neck and is just strangling him, the other is in the hands of George Lucas who isn’t paying the least bit of attention cause he’s too busy running toward a pile of cash which is of course causing him to just hoist Luke higher and actively killing him. BUT sitting on the wing is Mickey Mouse who is cutting through the rope.”

Hoe’s that for a mental image?
